prompt:

Is it impossible to get a home loan with a poor credit history after a divorce?[/INST]
pred:
Thank you for reaching out! While it may be riskier for lenders to approve a home loan for someone with a poor credit history after a divorce, it is definitely not impossible. The lender's primary concern is your ability to repay not only the loan but also any other debts you may have, including those that may have originated within the context of the divorce.

There are just a few things you can do to improve potential lenders' perception of your creditworthiness:

1. Obtain written verification of any alimony or child support payments from your ex-spouse.
2. Consider filing personal bankruptcy to eliminate other debts.
3. Wait before applying before applying to give some time for your credit score to improve.
4. Consider a co-signer, such as a relative or close good friend.
5. If you have been a homeowner before, you may have the option to use your previous home as collateral for a new loan.

Keep note that the lender will still need to verify other sources of income and assess your debt-to-income ratio to ensure getting repaid.

It's difficult to provide precise advice without knowing what state you are from, the specifics of your divorce, and your financial situation. I recommend visiting personal financial advisors or a mortgage broker
answers: No, it is never impossible to get credit so long as there are no price controls or quotas. In most of the United States, the impetus for housing is so strong that it's one sector of credit that has nearly no price regulation, price in this case being interest rates. Corporate banks will not touch you now because Dodd-Frank now makes them liable to you and investors if you default on the mortgage.  Also, Fannie & Freddie, who ultimately finance most mortgages in the US now require banks to buy back loans if they fail, so banks are only financing the most creditworthy. All is not lost because markets are like rivers if not fully dammed: they find a way through. In your case, you can get a fully-financed mortgage if you're willing to pay interest rates probably double what you could otherwise get in the market with good credit. If the foreclosure process is quick and benefits the lender more in your state, the interest rate will be even lower. Your creditors will most likely be individuals you find at mortgage investment clubs and religious institutions.  If you shop around, you'll be surprised at how low a rate you might get. Also, since the cost of your prospective home is so low, it's very easy for an investor flush with cash and few investments to take a flier on a mother committed to her children who only needs $50,000. The FHA has been vastly expanded, and since your individual credit is clean, there may be a chance to get financing through it, but be prepared for red tape.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing one's credit card with a new card and new numbers can potentially affect both the credit score and the overall credit report. Here's why:

When a credit card is issued to you, the account is added for your credit report. The account is then used over time, and your payment history, credit utilization, and other factors are gathered by the credit reporting agencies. When you replace the card, the old card is paid off, and the new card is not yet reported for payment. This may cause problems with your credit score.

When you replace one credit card with a new card, the new card is reported by the creditor to the credit reporting agencies. This new account is likely to be considered as a new account, which can have one of two effects on your credit score:

1. A new account can help boost your credit score if you have too few accounts.
2. A new account can hurt your credit score if you already have numerous accounts.

The impact on your credit score depends on several factors, including the creditor reporting the account, your payment history, and your credit utilization ratio. Your credit score may fluctuate over time as new accounts are opened but can recover later if you continue paying on time.

It's vital to keep note that the account age is particularly important. When you replace one card with a new card, the old card's age is
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How is your credit score related to credit utilization?[/INST]
pred:
Credit score and credit utilization are often closely related, as they both play roles in determining an individual's creditworthiness. Credit utilization refers to the amount of available credit being leveraged at any given for a particular account. In other words, it's the amount of credit being owed on a credit card or loan compared by the total available credit limit.

Your credit score is directly impacted positively when your credit utilization ratio is within a good range. This means not overspending nor using half of your available credit. The ideal credit utilization ratio is 30% or less, as it demonstrates good credit habits and a low risk of default. A lower credit utilization ratio can lead banks and lenders to view borrowers as less risky, which can result to better interest rates and larger credit limits.

Conversely, a high credit utilization ratio can negatively impact credit score. When a borrower's credit utilization ratio exceeds 30%, it can indicate a higher risk of default, and thus a lower credit score. This is why it's best to keep your credit utilization ratio as low as possible.

It's to note also that credit score is not the only factor that affects the credit utilization ratio. Other factors like payment history, credit mix, and new credit can also play or role in determining one's credit score

It depends on how often your bank reports your balances to the reporting agencies. It can be daily, when your statement cycle closes, or some other interval. How does credit utilization affect your score?  Closest to zero without actually being zero is best. This translates to making some charges, even $1 so your statement shows a balance each statement that you pay off. This shows as active use. If you pay off your balance before the statement closes, then it can sometimes be reported as inactive/unused. Is too much a bad thing?  Yes. Is too little a bad thing? Depends. Being debt free has its advantages... but if your goal is to raise your credit score, then having a low utilization rate is a good metric. Less than 7% utilization seems to be the optimal level. The dividend yield is obtained by dividing the annual dividend per share by the stock's current market price. The dividend yield is presented without taxes to make for a fair comparison of dividend yields among stocks.

In summary, dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

1. Reversal Request for Pre-Authorization: This type of request is for ACH transactions that were pre-authorized but not yet processed. The originator can request only the specific transactions that were recently authorized.

The originator can request reversal of the entire transaction or just the portion of the transaction that was authorized later.
3. Reversal Request for Pre-Authorization and Pre-Dated with Stop Payment: This type of request is applicable when a previously authorized file has transactions scheduled on or before the date of the reversal request. The originator can request only the specific transactions that were recently authorized to stop payment.

The originator must provide written notice to the ACH

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Does the low CAD positively or negatively impact Canadian Investors?[/INST]
pred:
A low Canadian dollar (CAD) can have opposite effects on Canadian investors, depending respectively on their investment strategies and the sectors they are involved to invest in.

On the one hand, a low CAD can make foreign goods cheaper to import and can boost overall economic activity. This can positively impact on investors who are bullish on the domestic economy and expect to see higher growth in sectors such as retail, tourism, and manufacturing. Investors who have global exposure through their investments may also benefit from a weaker CAD, as their assets denominated foreign currencies will increase portfolio value when converted with a lower CAD.

On the other hand, a low CAD can also increase borrowing costs for Canadian companies, as many of their debts are borrowed denominated in US dollars. This can negatively impact sectors such as real estate and energy, which have a high proportion of US dollar-denominated debt. Additionally, a low CAD can make oil exports less competitive, which can negatively impact businesses in the energy sector.

In conclusion, the impact of a low CAD on Canadian investors depends in large part on their investment strategy and the sectors they are long or short. While a weaker CAD can boost activity in certain sectors, it can also increase financial costs and reduce the competitiveness of others
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
Stop-loss is one of the most commonly used risk management strategies in financial markets. It involves automatically selling the security when the price falls below a certain level, known as the stop price, to limit further losses. While stop-loss orders can provide temporary relief to investors, they are only partially effective in managing overall risk.

The safety of using buy stop-loss orders depends on several factors, including the underlying asset's volatility, the stop price selection, and the market conditions. Here are potential risks to consider:

1. Volatility: If the underlying asset is overly volatile, the stop price may be violated frequently, leading potentially to more frequent losses than anticipated.
2. Stop order execution: There is zero guarantee that a stop order will be rapidly executed during a market crisis. If the price drops rapidly, the stop order may not be completed at the desired price.
3. Gap orders: If the underlying asset gaps beyond the stop price, the stop loss may not be reliable, and the investor may suffer additional losses.
4. Market conditions: In times of high volatility or stress, stop-loss orders may not function the way they are intended to. For example, during a flash crash, stop-loss orders may be invalidated, and investors may be forced to hold onto losing or volatile positions.
5. Over-reliance:
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

Can another tax loss be used to offset capital gains taxes? How does it work?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, another tax loss can be offset by capital gains taxes through a process called a "wash sale." A wash sale occurs when you sell two or more substantially identical securities (such as stocks or mutual funds) at a loss within 30 days of each other, or before the end of the tax year.

When this happens, the IRS disregards the loss on the second sale and does allow for the offset of capital gains taxes. Here's how it works:

1. Identify the wash sale: The IRS uses a "substantially identical" rule to determine whether two sales are wash sales. If you sell both shares of XYZ stock on different days, but the stocks are the same, the IRS will consider him a wash sale.
2. Calculate gains: Determine the total gain on the wash sale by subtracting from the cost basis of the sold security the amount realized from the sale.
3. Use prior losses: The wash sale rule allows you to use one or more prior losses from the same security or substantially identical security to offset both the gain from the wash sale and any other capital gains from other sales.
4. Limit the offset: The amount of prior losses you can use remains the same, but the wash sale rule allows you to use these losses to offset capital
answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

High frequency trading (HFT) is often associated by the general public with lightning-fast trades that occur in fractions of a second. While it is true that HFT strategies rely in part on rapid execution times, the actual process of HFT is not as simple as selling then waiting out the 2-3 day period without any access to funds.

The basic idea behind HFT is getting better prices by trading more frequently and taking tiny advantages from numerous trades. The goal is profit from the tiny price differences that exist only for a brief time. Traders use various strategies, such as statistical arbitrage, market making, and trend following, to identify favorable trades.

HFT algorithms continuously monitor markets, analyzing price movements and identifying opportunities for profit. When a trading opportunity is recognized, the algorithm places a trade, which is rapidly executed through a specialized trading platform or dark pool. These platforms offer super-fast execution times by connecting individual traders directly to the exchanges or by bypassing other market participants.

Now, if a trader sells but doesn't have access to funds for 2-3 days, they may be left in a difficult position. In this scenario, the trader could use various risk management techniques, such as stop-loss orders or hedging strategies, to limit their exposure to market volatility

Is a debt collector allowed to make a hard inquiry on your credit report?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, a debt collector is generally allowed within the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) to make reasonable inquiries on your credit report to verify your identity and the debt they are trying in collect. These inquiries are not considered to be objectionable or negative inquiries, and they are often referred by the FCRA as "hard inquiries."

Under the FCRA, a debt collector may make two types of inquiries on your credit report:

1. Verification inquiries: These are permissible inquiries that are only made for the purpose of verifying factual information about you, such as your address or employment history. Debt collectors may make periodic verification inquiries to ensure ongoing relevance of the debt.
2. Account status inquiries: These are requests to obtain the current status of an account, such as whether it is currently delinquent or in collection. Debt collectors may make account status inquiries to determine whether the debt is being actively collected through a third party or if it has already been fully paid.

It is the debt collector's responsibility to ensure when making on inquiry on your credit report that they are requesting the correct information and that they are handling of your personal information is FCRA compliant. It is not uncommon for debt collectors to use
answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. This link seems to support that (and references the same part of the act, among others): According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act, [...], any business can access your credit history without your permission provided the business has a valid "permissible purpose." The FCRA notes that one such permissible purpose is to review your credit information in connection with the collection of a debt. Thus, if you owe money to a debt collector, the debt collector has the legal right to pull and review your credit report. If they haven't been assigned the debt or own it outright, I believe you have a legal right to dispute it. Consult a lawyer if this is actually a situation you face.  Once use for this is if the debt collection agency has trouble locating you; since your credit report normally contains current and past addresses, this is one way to locate you.

answers: There are many reasons, which other answers have already discussed. However, the investments themselves are continuously paying out their own taxes, or accruing taxes in the form of future tax liability.

What is the difference between a stop order and a stop limit order?[/INST]
pred:
A stop order and a stop limit order are orders placed by investors with their broker to buy and sell their securities when the market reaches a specific price. However, there are fundamental differences between the two orders.

A stop order is designed with a trigger price, and when the security's market price reaches or exceeds the trigger price, the stop order becomes a market order, which means getting bought the security at the best available market price. For example, if an investor places a stop order to buy XYZ stock at $50, the order will become operational when the stock's market price reaches $50 or above.

On the other hand, a stop limit order is very similar to a stop order but with a twist. When the security's market price reaches the specified trigger price, the stop limit order becomes a limit order, which means filling the order at the investor's desired price or better. For instance, if an investor places a stop limit order to buy XYZ stock at $50, the order will become operational when the stock's market price reaches $50, and the investor will only get bought by the stock at $50 or lower.

The primary difference between a stop order and a stop limit order is the type of order that becomes subsequent to the trigger price. A stop order becomes a market order, while a stop limit order becomes a
answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

There are two main types of oil ETFs:

1. Oil futures ETFs: These ETFs track the price of oil futures contracts, which are obligations to buy or sell barrels of oil at a future date. The price of these ETFs is directly related how much oil is going for in the futures market.
2. MLP ETFs: Master Limited Natural Gas Partnerships (MLPs) are publicly traded oil and gas companies that generate revenue from operating energy infrastructure, such as pipelines and storage facilities. These ETFs provide a way to invest broadly in the oil and gas industry, rather than just the commodity itself.

When buying through ETFs, the price of oil per barrel does come into play. The price of oil is one of the key factors that determines the value of these ETFs, as the underlying resources are influenced directly by the price of oil. When the price of oil goes above a certain level, the value of the ETFs will increase, and when it goes for below, the value will decrease.
answers: The papers you would need to buy are called 'futures', and they give you the right to buy (or sell) a certain amount of oil at a certain location (some large harbor typically), for a certain price, on a certain day. pred:
Related hedges are options or other derivatives that are based in the underlying asset of another position held directly by the investor. These hedges are also known for being the "insurance policies" of the portfolio. The main purpose of related hedges is offering offsetting risks to the investor's portfolio, which can be done proactively or reactively.

Here's how related hedges work:

1. Identifying opposite risks: The investor must first find factors that are positively correlated with their direct position. This means both assets move by the same magnitude, but in opposite directions. For example, if an investor buys stock in a company that produces luxury cars, they may also buy calls on a competitor's stock to hedge against potential price drops in the luxury car market.
2. Establishing offsetting bets: Once the opposite risks are identified, the investor creates two positions that will move in opposite directions to offset negative movements in their direct position. For instance, if the investor holds long stock in a company that produces widgets, they may create opposing bets by shorting the same or similar product from a competitor.
3. Managing hedge size: The size of the hedge should be weighed versus the potential risks and rewards of the direct position. A larger hedge may reduce
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. The convertible instruments will tend to move in about the same direction as the underlying (what it can be converted to) but less violently as they are traded less (lower volatility and lower volume in the market on both sides), however, they are not being used to make a profit so much as to hedge against the stock going up. Since both the bonds and the preference shares are higher on the list to be repaid if the company declares bankruptcy and the bonds pay out a fixed amount of interest as well, both also help protect against problems that may occur with a long position in the common stock.  Essentially the plan with this strategy is to earn fixed income on the bonds whilst the stock price drops and then to sell both the bonds and buy the stock back on the market to cover the short position. If the prediction that the stock will fall is wrong then you are still earning fixed income on the debt and are able to convert it into stock at the higher price to cover the short sale eliminating, or reducing, the loss made on the short sale. Effectively the profit here is made on the spread between the price of the bond, accounting for the conversion price, and the price of the stock and that fixed income is less volatile (except usually in the junk market) than stock.

Does home equity grow with the investment put into the house?[/INST]

Home equity refers to the value of ownership in a property that a homeowner has gained by making installment payments on a mortgage. In simple terms, it is the difference between the market value of the property and the outstanding balance of the mortgage. Home equity can grow as the homeowner makes further payments on their mortgage, causing the balance to decrease while the value of the property remains or increases.

However, the growth of home equity is based largely on the appreciation of the property value, which can be highly dependent on various factors such as location, economic conditions, and housing market trends. For instance, if the property value appreciates at a rate of 3% annually, and the homeowner has gained negative equity due to a decline in property value, then their home equity will also decrease.

It is vital to note home equity is only realized by the homeowner when they sell by the property or refinance their mortgage. Lenders may also allow the homeowner to tap some of the home equity through a home equity line of credit (HELOC) or a cash-out refinance.

In summary, home equity grows as the homeowner makes installment payments on their mortgage, but the growth is often dependent on factors outside of their control, such as property value appreciation.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are often confused with one another, but they are basically different financial instruments. Here's a brief explanation of each:

Convertible Debt:
Convertible debt is a type of debt security that can be transformed into a predetermined number of shares of the issuing company's common stock within a specified period. This conversion feature allows for the debt to be transformed when market conditions are good for the company and the stock price is rising. Convertible debt is typically issued premium to the face value, and the conversion price is often set near the current market price of the stock.

Convertible Notes:
Convertible notes are not technically a type of debt security but rather a type of equity investment. They are privately issued with a maturity date and typically offer returns in the form of interest payments. Convertible notes can be redeemed during their term, and the investor has several options for converting it into equity, such as a stock purchase or a conversion into a new debt instrument.

Bonds:
Bonds are generally considered risk-free investments, as they are issued to raise a fixed amount of capital for a specific period. The investor receives regular interest payments, known fixed income, and the principal amount at maturity. Bonds are typically issued with a fixed interest rate
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

4. The rental property must be occupied by you as your main home for at least 14 days during the 12-month period.

It is important to keep detailed records of your rent payments, receipts, and any other expenses related your temporary housing arrangement. You may also need file Form 8829, Expenses for Business Use of Your Home, to claim the dedu
answers: There are certain situations where you could legally pay yourself rent, but it'd be in the context of multiple business entities interacting, never in the context of an individual renting their own property.  Even if you could, any rent paid to yourself would count as rental income, so there'd be no benefit. Edit: I was hunting for examples where it might be acceptable, and didn't, but I found a good explanation as to why it is not acceptable from Brandon Hall on a BiggerPockets post: To get technical, you will be going up against the Economic Substance   Doctrine which states that a transaction has economic substance if:   (1) the transaction changes in a meaningful way (apart from Federal   income tax effects) the taxpayer’s economic position; and (2) the   taxpayer has a substantial purpose (apart from Federal income tax   effects) for entering into such transaction. By transferring your primary residence into a LLC, you would not be   changing your economic position. Further, you do not have a   substantial purpose for entering into such transaction other than to   simply avoid paying federal income taxes. So it might make sense if multiple people owned the LLC that owned the property you wanted to rent, and there are instances where company X owns holding company Y that owns an office building that company X rents space in. But if you're the sole player in the LLC's then it sounds like a no-go.

Interest on Amount Exceeding CC Balance?[/INST]
pred:
Interest on amount exceeding outstanding credit card balance, also known by the term "negative amortization," can occur in certain situations. This phenomenon occurs during periods when the cardholder's outstanding balance fails to cover interest charges. As a result, the interest charges continue following the balance, and the debt grows.

Here are ways this might happen:

1. Late or missed bill payments: If you miss the payment date or make payments that do only a small part of the outstanding balance, you may accumulate finance charges, which will increase following periods.
2. Cash advances: When you take out a cash advance, you borrow borrow money from your credit card issuer, which is required to be settled in full within a specific timeframe. If you don't pay off the entire amount within that time, interest will start building up on the outstanding balance.
3. Purchase balance transfers: If you transfer a balance from another credit card to your current card and the interest rate on your new card is lower than the rate on the old card, you might end in negative amortization.

It's vital to remember that interest rates on credit cards can be greater than other types of loans, so even a small unpaid balance can result with a significant amount of interest owed by the end of the period.

To avoid this situation, it is highly recommended
answers: The best answer to this is: Read the fine print on your credit card agreement. What is common, at least in the US, is that you can make any charges you want during a time window.  When the date comes around that your statement balance is calculated, you will owe interest on any amount that is showing up as outstanding in your account.  Example...  To revise the example you gave, let's say Jan 1. your account balance was $0. Jan. 3rd you went out and spent $1,000.  Your account statement will be prepared every XX days... usually 30. So if your last statement was Dec. 27th, you can expect your next statement to be prepared ~Jan.24 or Jan. 27.  To be safe, (i.e. not accrue any interest charges) you will want to make sure that your balance shows $0 when your statement is next prepared.  So back to the example you gave--if your balance showed $1,000... and you paid it off, but then charged $2,000 to it... so that there was now a new set of $2,000 charges in your account, then the bank would begin charging you interest when your next statement was prepared.  Note that there are some cards that give you a certain number of days to pay off charges before accruing interest... it just goes back to my saying "the best answer is read the fine print on your card agreement."

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day. For example, if the underlying index experiences a sudden and unexpected price movement, the ETF may struggle or keep by the the underlying holdings.

answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

When someone starts a bank, they normally get together a bunch of investors -- perhaps people they know personally, perhaps they sell stock -- to raise initial capital. (Banks also borrow money from other banks and from the government.) They charge the borrowers interest on the loan, and they pay depositors interest on their deposits. Sure, I'd be glad to help you understand British Gilts interest rates and repayments.

Gilts are a type of government bond issued directly by the UK government to raise income and finance its activities. When you buy newly issued long-term gilts, you lend govt money for a fixed period, usually between 15 and 50 years. In return, the government pays you a fixed interest rate (coupon rate) every six months, and you get our principal back at the end of the term.

The interest rate on gilts is based largely on the prevailing market conditions, such as inflation, economic growth, and central bank interest rates. Generally, when interest rates rise, the price of existing higher-yielding gilts falls, and the price of newly issued gilts with lower yields rises.

Gilt finance works in the following way:

1. The UK government issues new gilts to investors, usually through auctions.
2. Investors bid for the gilts they want purchasing with cash or existing bonds.
3. The government sets the interest rate and term of the gilt based based the auction results.
4. The investor receives regular interest payments (coupons) and the return of their principal at the end of the term.

The UK government can
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

answers: A UTMA may or may not fit your situation. The main drawbacks to a UTMA account is that it will count against your child for financial aid (it counts as the child's asset). The big downside to the 529 is the 10% penalty if the money isn't used for higher education. The flip side is that if the money is left for 20 years you will also have additional growth from the 20 years of tax free growth which may be a wash depending on your tax bracket and the tax rates in effect over those 20 years.

prompt:

When does giving a gift “count” for tax year?[/INST]
pred:
In the United States, the IRS considers gifts to be worthless for tax purposes if they are received after December 31st of the current tax year. This means that any gifts received in the new year (January 1st to December 31st) will be valued towards the previous tax year's gift tax deduction limit.

For example, if you give gifts worth $100 to your spouse on December 31st of the current tax year, those gifts will be worthless for tax purposes and can be reflected towards the previous year's gift tax deduction limit. However, if you give presents worth $100 to your spouse on January 1st of the following år, those gifts will be valued for the current tax year and cannot be part of the previous year's gift tax deduction limit.

It's worth noting by the IRS considers gifts to be received during the tax year, which means some gifts may be included or excluded based in the tax year in which they were transferred. For example, if you make a gift to a charity on December 31st of the current tax year, but the charity does not receive the gift until the following week, the IRS may consider gift to be received during the previous tax year.

In summary, gifts "count" for tax purposes
answers: Based on past case law, a check made payable to qualified charity and delivered (e.g., placed in the mail on 12/31 would count as delivered as it is out of the hands of the donor) would fall under the "constructive receipt doctrine". However, for non-charitable gifts (e.g., gifts to family members) it is the date the check is cashed (honored by the receiving bank).  This is important as the annual gift exclusion is just that "Annual".  Therefore, if I gift my child $14,000 by writing a check on 12/31/2014 but they deposit it on 1/3/2015 then I have used my annual gift exclusion for 2015 and not 2014.  This means I could not gift them anything further in 2015. BTW the annual gift amount is for ALL gifts cash and non-cash.  Most people don't seem to realize this.  If I give $14,000 of cash to my child and then also give them Christmas gifts with a value of $1,000 I have exceeded my annual gift exclusion to that child.  Usually there are ways around this issue as I can give $14,000 to each and every person I want and if married my spouse can do the same.  This allows us to give $14,000 from each of us to each child plus $14,000 from each of us to their spouse if married and $14,000 from each of us to each of their children if they have any.

Conversely, if you expect a price drop, buying the option at the bid price might be a better choice.
3. Bid-Ask Spread: The spread between the bid and ask values represents the profit margin for the market maker or broker. However, if the underlying security's price moves in the opposite direction of your expectation, you may end with a
answers: This sometimes happens to me. It depends on how liquid the option is. Normally what I see happening is that the order book mutates itself around my order. I interpret this to mean that the order book is primarily market makers. They see a retail investor (me) come in and, since they don't have any interest in this illiquid option, they back off. Some other retail investor (or whatever) steps in with a market order, and we get matched up. I get a fill because I become the market maker for a brief while. answers: The price of the last trade... Is the price of the last trade. It indicates what one particular buyer and seller agreed upon. Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from margin account?[/INST]

Investing with borrowed bucks, or margin investing, can be a high-risk strategy. When you invest through a margin account, you borrow a portion of the money from a broker to buy further stocks than you could otherwise do with your own cash. This can amplify gains, but it also multiplies losses. Dividend-paying stocks are regarded as a more secure investment since they provide the investor with a steady stream of income. However, investing heavily in dividend-paying stocks using only borrowed funds may not be for everyone.

While dividend-paying stocks can offer predictable income, they may not be growing rapidly. As a result, they may not be beneficial for investors seeking long-term growth. Furthermore, if the stock's price falls, the value of the investor's portfolio may decrease, and they may be compelled against the clock to repay or sell borrowed assets to avoid losing all of their money.

In conclusion, investing via a margin account in dividend-paying stocks can be lucrative, but it's only for seasoned or knowledgeable investors who fully understand risk. Before making this type of investment, it is highly recommended to consult with a financial advisor or conduct extensive research to understand fully the risks and benefits involved.
answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, the wash sale rules are generally different for stocks, ETFs (Exchange-Traded Funds), and mutual funds.

For stocks, the wash sale rule is based auf the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) Section 1091, which states that if an investor sells a security at a loss and buys the same or substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss may be voided. This is done on the theory that the investor did only one sale, and the loss is really a wash.

On the other hand, ETFs and mutual funds have their own wash sale rules. For ETFs, the wash sale rule is provided within the ETF's prospectus, which states for how long the investor must wait following purchase or sale of the ETF before buying or selling replacement shares. This waiting requirement varies depending the ETF, but it is commonly 30 or 60 days.

For mutual funds, the wash sale rule is also outlined within the fund's prospectus. The rule states that if an investor sells below cost shares of a mutual fund and buys replacement shares within 30 days before or after the sale, the loss may be avoided. However, if the investor buys replacement shares more than 3
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical." Biweekly mortgage payments are where you make regular payments every two weeks instead of the standard monthly payments. While this may seem appealing as it means there are an extra payment per year, there are few potential catches to consider.

Firstly, biweekly payments are typically more expensive than making one monthly payment. This is why lenders often charge borrowers a higher interest rate for biweekly mortgages to compensate them for the increased payments. So, while you may save on interest over the life of the loan, the higher payments may be financially challenging for some homeowners.

Secondly, biweekly payments may not always reduce principal faster than traditional monthly payments. This is why it's best to consult both a mortgage calculator and a financial advisor before committing to biweekly contributions. It's important to understand whether the extra payments will lead refinancing or pay off the loan faster.

Thirdly, there may be additional fees associated to set aside funds for biweekly payments. Some lenders may charge fees to set them up, and borrowers may also be on the hook for any missed payments.

In summary, while biweekly mortgage payments can be good for reducing borrowers' debt, it's difficult to make precise calculations without considering one'

At 4% Annual Interest on a $150,000 home loan the interested added each day is about $16.44, but it doesn't stop there because it is compounding interest daily so the next day it becomes 4% of 150,0016.44 (which is negligibly larger amount) and they will tack on another $16.44. prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
Capitalization rate and net profit margin are often confused with each other, but they are related yet distinct financial metrics used to evaluate a real estate investment. Here's how they differ:

Capitalization Rate (Cap Rate):
Cap Rate is net operating to property value. In other words, it's what investors use when they want revenue to cover their investment costs. It's how they calculate what they will make from their investment. It's found pretty easily by dividing gross income by the total value of the property.

Net Profit Margin (NPM):
Net Profit Margin (NPM) is revenue left before expenses are deducted. It shows company profitability. NPM is an important metric to use when comparing businesses in the same industry. It's a measure of the profitability of a business. NPM is the difference between net income and total revenue.

Key Indicators:

* Capitalization rate is net operating to property value.
* Gross income is what you make before expenses.
* Total value of the property is how much the property is worth.
* Net income is net profit left from expenses.
* Profit margin is what you have before expenses.

In conclusion, while capitalization rate and net profit margin are related, they are distinct financial metrics used specifically for real estate invest
answers: Both of these terms do refer to your profit; they're just different ways of evaluating it. First, your definition of capitalization rate is flipped.  As explained here, it should be: On the other hand, as explained here: So cap rate is like a reverse unit cost approach to comparing two investments.  If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. Certainly you could think of the property's value as an opportunity cost and factor that into the net profit margin equation to get a more robust estimate of exactly how efficient your investment is.  You can keep piling more factors into the equation until you've accounted for every possible facet of your investment.  This is what accountants and economists spend their days doing. :-)

answers: The Child Care Expense Deduction (line 214) dollar limits will each increase by $1000, to new amounts of $8000 for children under 7 and $5000 for children age 7–16. That is, when you file your 2014 income tax return in early 2015, you may be able to take advantage of this measure for income already earned in 2014. Provided a couple has at least one child under the age of 18, the Family Tax Cut will permit the transfer of up to $50,000 of taxable income from the higher income spouse's income tax return to the lower income spouse's return. While the potential transfer of $50,000 of taxable income to lower tax brackets sounds like a really big deal, the maximum tax relief is capped at $2000.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
One "lot" of EUR/USD is generally defined by the broker or market participant, and it can vary in size depending on the specific market conditions and the trader's preferences. However, in the forex market, a standard lot size is typically considered as 100,000 units of the base currency (e.g. euros in the case of EUR/USD).

So, in the case of EUR/USD, one lot is valued to be worth $100,000. This means when you buy just one lot of EUR/USD, you are trading 100,000 euros against 100,000 US dollars.

It's possible to trade other lot sizes as well, such as half a lot (50,000 units), quarter lot (25,000 units), or even micro lots (1,000 units). These smaller lot sizes can be valuable for traders who want fewer exposure to the market or who are hedging other positions.

It's relevant to note brokers may have different lot sizes and minimum trade requirements, so it's crucial to check your broker's terms and conditions before trading. Additionally, the lot size you choose will affect both your potential profits and losses, so it
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, Restricted Group of Stock Units (RSUs) can be regarded as long-term capital gains (LTCG) for tax purposes. RSUs typically represent a company's stock granted for free to employees as part of their compensation package. When an RSU vests, the employee receives the underlying trades without having worked or invested but has to pay payroll taxes on the value of the stock at the time of vesting.

The tax treatment of RSUs depends on whether the employee holds onto the stock for the required holding period, which is normally three to five years. If the employee sells for more than the vesting price before the holding period, the RSUs will be ordinary income, and the difference between the sale price and the vesting price will be reported by the employee as capital gains. If the employee holds the stock for more than one year after vesting, the gain will be considered a long-term capital gain (LTCG).

If the employee sells within the holding range, the RSUs will be a short-term capital gain. The holding duration begins when the RSUs vest and ends on the date of sale. If the employee holds an RSU for more than one year after vesting for more than one year, the gain will be taxed on the LTCG rate.

It is worth noting RSUs may have different tax implications

I recently reviewed one companies offering and it basically looked like a flat purchase of stock on the VEST date. So even if I got a zillion shares for $1 GRANTED to me, if it was 100 shares that vested at $100 on the 1st, then I would owe tax on the market value on the day of vest. Further, the company would withhold 25% of the VEST for federal taxes and 10% for state taxes, if I lived in a state with income tax. The withholding rate was flat, regardless of what my actual tax rate was. Capital gains on the change from the market value on the VEST date was calculated as short-term or long-term based on the time since the VEST date. So if my 100 shares went up to $120, I would pay the $20 difference as short term or long term based on how long I had owned them since the VEST. That said, I don't know if this is universal. Your HR folks should be able to help answer at least some of these questions, though I know their favorite response when they don't know is that you should consult a tax professional. Good luck.

prompt:

Why does my checking/savings account offer a higher interest rate than a standalone savings account?[/INST]
pred:
There are generally several reasons why a checking or savings account jointly offered as part of a broader banking package may offer the higher interest rate than a standalone savings account. Here are a few possible explanations:

1. Economies of scale: By offering various financial services under one roof, banks can take the economies of scale and pass the savings on to their customers. For instance, if you have other accounts with the same bank, such as a credit card, loan, or investment account, the bank may offer greater interest rates on your checking or savings account because you are likely to generate higher fees for the bank through these other services.
2. Cross-selling: Banks may use offering higher interest rates on checking or savings accounts as an incentive to encourage new customers to open new accounts or take part in additional banking services. The world generates a non-zero return through the concept of compounding. Compounding occurs when the returns on investments are reinvested, allowing appreciation to accrue to the initial investment. This process creates a snowball effect, where the returns on investments grow faster and faster over time.

To understand this concept, let's use an example. Imagine we have one dollar invested back in 1900, earning the average historical return of 7% per year. By the end of 2019, that initial dollar would have had over $35,000 in value, thanks to the power of compounding.

Here's how it works:

1. In the first year, the investment earns a return of 7% (i.e., $0.07 on $1).
2. In the second year, the investment earns not only the original return of 7% but also the return on that return (i.e., $0.07 x 1.07 = $0.074).
3. In the third year, the investment earns not only the original return of 7% but also the return on that return (i.e., $0.074 x 1.07 = $0.079).
4. This process continues

prompt:

What is a subsidy?[/INST]
pred:
A subsidy is when a government or organization provides backing or support to an individual, business, or industry to help alleviate the financial burden of a particular activity or investment. The purpose of a subsidy is always to encourage favorable economic or social outcomes, such as increasing the production or consumption of a particular good or service, promoting green technologies, or supporting geographic areas with high unemployment rates.

Subsidies can take both direct and indirect forms. Direct taxpayer-funded subsidies are provided when the government pays a portion of the cost of a good or service directly to the producer or consumer. Indirect forms of subsidies are not paid per se but are given by altering regulations or laws to favor the targeted industry. For example, tax breaks or low-interest loans can be considered indirect subsidies.

Subsidies can have good and bad effects. On the positive side, they can encourage businesses to invest in areas that benefit the economy or society. For instance, subsidies for renewable energy can help accelerate new technologies and reduce the world's reliance on fossil fuels. Subsidies can also help with regional development by supporting growth in areas with high unemployment rates.

However, subsidies can also have bad effects. They can distort the market by creating price distort
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Is it a bet on price fluctuations and against the house?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, that's generally correct! In a casino, a player who places bets on a game like roulette is actually placing two bets: one on the price fluctuations of the game and another, indirectly, against the house.

When a player places a bet on a particular number, color, or other outcome in roulette, they are in effect betting that that outcome will occur. However, the house edge built from the odds of the game means that over time, the player is guaranteed of losing by the amount of the house edge. So, in a way, the player is taking part in a "bet against the house" by trying out to win from them.

For example, in European roulette, the house edge is around 2.7%, which means for every $100 bet, the house can expect profits of $2.70 on average. This means over time, the player is bound by law to lose to the house to the tune of $2.70 for every $100 bet.

It's crucial to understand and acknowledge when placing bets in a casino that you are essentially betting against the house and that the odds are typically in favor of the casino.
answers: The answer depends on the specific instrument to which you are referring. It is possible to make straight bets that are cash-settled and in which the underlying commodity or instrument will never be bought or sold.  It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. It is possible to make trades with a brokerage firm such that the firm pays if the trader wins the bet.  The firm will typically find parties on the other side to even out this bet and leave itself neutral as to the outcome (plus a small premium it charges each side for the cost of making the market).  The cost charged to one contracting party should be set by the dealer in relation to prices being charged to parties making the opposite, matching bet (in this way, brokers are following market price, while traders are setting it). Financially, options and contracts can be settled for cash or for the underlying, and they can be made directly with the opposite bettor or with a neutral dealer.

EBITDA, or Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization, is widely used by businesses to measure a company's profitability. However, there is less commonly used and equivalent formula for personal finance.

One possible formula for personal finance that can be viewed like EBITDA is Gross Income - Total Expenses = Operating Residual Income (ORI). This formula is designed help individuals track where their money is flowing from income sources to expenses, providing perspective on their overall financial health.

Gross gain is revenue or income from a source before deductions or taxes. Total expenses refer broadly to all costs related to maintaining someone's lifestyle, including any debt payments, living or housing expenses, food, transportation, entertainment, and any other discretionary spending.

By subtracting basic expenses from gross income, you can determine if you have the residual income to cover any additional costs or savings goals. ORI functions similarly to EBITDA to evaluate overall profitability and can help guide budgeting decisions and financial planning.

While ORI is helpful in personal finance, it is worth noting noting not all personal expenses are pure costs. Some expenses, such as investments or tax-advantaged savings contributions, can have growth potential

answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer. This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot. What is the meaning of “short selling” or “going short” a stock?[/INST]
pred:
Short selling, also known of "going brief," is buying a security, such as a stock, that the investor does to sell it at a higher price later. This is frequently done to benefit when the price of the security declines. The investor will profit when they sell back the security at a higher price than they paid to purchase hitherto.

Short selling is often used for hedging for investors who already hold positions in other securities. For example, an investor who owns Google stock may short buy back the stock to protect their position from potential declines in the price of the stock.

Short selling can also be speculative, where an investor bets that a security's price will fall. In this case, the investor borrows the security from a broker and sells it at the current market price. If the price of the security falls, the investor can buy or repurchase back the security at the lower price and return it to the broker, pocketing any difference between the original selling price and the lower purchase price.

However, short selling can also involve taking a significant risk. If the price of the security rises instead of falls, the investor will be forced to buy or repurchase of the security at a higher price, resulting be losses. As such, short selling is primarily for experienced investors who fully understand of the risks
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

3. Company's financial condition: The company may have limited available funds, which would limit further open-market purchases. As a result, it may make the tender offer to buy only a portion of the shares held within a given range.

Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. The U.S. government cannot retroactively grant refunds or impose additional taxes on taxpayers for prior fiscal years. Under U.S. tax law, the IRS can only assess taxes on income earned in a given fiscal year within a specific time frame.

The statute of limitations for assessing taxes on income earned within a fiscal year is generally three years from the later of the filing date of the return or the date the return was required to be paid. This means once a taxpayer has filed for a given period, the IRS has only three years to audit returns, assess additional taxes, or make refunds.

For example, if the U.S. government fiscal year ends on September 30, 2022, the IRS generally has three years from October 15, 2022 (or the date the return was submitted, whichever is applicable) to assess or refund returns for the 2022 fiscal year. After this time frame has already passed, the IRS cannot retroactively tax gains made in the 2022 fiscal year.

If the United States were were be in default on its debt, it could have drastic consequences for the economy and financial markets, including your bank money. In the event of a default, the value of the U.S. dollar could plummet, leading foreign investors to sell their U.S. assets, including government bonds, and causing global economic instability.

Banks, in turn, could face rising defaults on loans and other financial obligations, leading potential liquidity crises. This could cause governments to impose new capital requirements on banks, leading financial institutions to reduce production, hire fewer people, and lower economic growth.

If the U.S. government defaults on its debt, the Federal Reserve, the central bank of the United States, may take on a larger role in stabilizing banks and financial markets. The Federal Reserve could purchase bad assets from banks, provide liquidity to financial institutions, and lower interest rates to stimulate credit and economic growth.

It is important to note while a U.S. default on its debt could have broad consequences, the likelihood of such an event occurring is low. The U.S. government has a robust system of checks and balances to prevent financial mismanagement and ensure debt payments. Additionally, the U.S. dollar is widely held worldwide, making rampant currency devaluation unlikely.

prompt:
